page.title: 04THE COASTLINE AT AMBLE
page.content: Amble's{coastline}is a{sandy beach}to the south leading to the{Panhaven {Rocks}where salt was panned in earlier times.{Cliff House}overlooks the {harbour entrance,}the{north pier}of which has recently been repaired. Northwards the coastline is again sandy, behind which lies{dunes and {marshland,}once the{mouth of the river Coquet. Inland the{land is low-lying {farmland,}with the exception that {Amble itself has grown}towards the coast. To the south a massive crane dominates during the prescence of{open {cast mining operations.}From Amble harbour,{now denuded of its staithes {and colliers}but with its{fishing {vessels and sailing craft,}can be seen the{ruined keep of Warkworth Castle and the village upstream. The Coquet is{tidal to the weir,}beyond which it begins its{defence of the village.
